awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Multiparty Communication, Polynomials, and Noise
awd_abstract_narration:
Communication complexity theory studies the minimum amount of communication, measured in bits, required in order to compute functions whose arguments are distributed among several parties. In addition to the basic importance of studying communication as a bottleneck resource, the theory has found a vast number of applications in many areas, including machine learning, mechanism design, streaming algorithms, data structures, pseudo-random generators, and VLSI layouts. This project tackles fundamental questions whose resolution will have a significant impact on the discipline. This work will exploit insights from, and contribute new ideas to, other areas such as quantum computing, computational learning, and approximation theory. The project is an ample source of research problems at various levels of difficulty and will be used in advising graduate and undergraduate students.  The investigator will integrate this research into his graduate and undergraduate teaching, take an active part in scientific dissemination, and promote theoretical computer science in Southern California.

This project comprises two related components.  First, the investigator will tackle longstanding open problems in the study of multiparty communication, such as settling the communication requirements of the set disjointness problem and breaking the logarithmic barrier for multiparty communication lower bounds. The second, complementary component of this project will advance the study of analytic representations of Boolean functions. Here, the investigator aims to obtain tight lower bounds for the polynomial approximation and sign-representation of the k-element distinctness function, constant-depth circuits, and Boolean formulas of arbitrary depth.  The two research components of this project are intimately related in that they require the same class of analytic techniques. Indeed, major advances in communication complexity over the past two decades have been obtained by transforming, explicitly or implicitly, communication protocols into multivariate polynomials of comparable complexity and by analyzing the resulting approximation questions. The planned research on multiparty communication and polynomials is further unified by a focus on noise, in the sense of imperfect output or adversarial corruption of intermediate computations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

Communication complexity theory is a central branch of theoretical computer science that studies the minimum amount of communication required to compute functions whose arguments are distributed among several parties. In addition to the basic importance of studying communication as a bottleneck resource, the theory has applications to virtually every research topic in theoretical computer science and beyond. As part of this project, the investigator resolved several challenging questions in communication complexity theory.

In more detail, it has been a longstanding challenge to obtain optimal lower bounds on the communication requirements of the circuit class AC0, defined as the class of polynomial-size constant-depth circuits with AND, OR, NOT gates of unbounded fan-in. We resolved this challenge in three notoriously hard models of communication. 

  • We obtained essentially optimal lower bounds on the unbounded-error communication complexity and sign-rank of AC0 circuits.
  • We studied AC0 circuits in the two most powerful models of bounded-error communication: the multiparty number-on-the-forehead model and quantum model. In both cases, we proved that the simplest objects in AC0 (namely, polynomial-size DNF formulas) already have essentially the maximum possible communication complexity.

These results are a polynomial improvement on previous work. We obtained them by analyzing the approximation of AC0 circuits by real polynomials. Our approximation-theoretic contributions, stated below, close an extensive line of research and are of significant interest in their own right.

  • The approximate degree of a Boolean function f is the minimum degree of a real polynomial p that approximates f pointwise within 1/3. We proved that polynomial-size DNF formulas have essentially the maximum possible approximate degree. Previously, such a strong result was only known for AC0 circuits of very large depth.
  • The threshold degree of a Boolean function f is the minimum degree of a real polynomial p that sign-represents f pointwise: sign(p(x))=(-1)f(x) for all x. We obtained near-optimal lower bounds on the threshold degree of AC0 circuits.

Lastly, we studied the comparative power of quantum versus classical query algorithms. For every integer k≥1, we gave a problem whose bounded-error query complexity is k in the quantum model and at least ~Ω(n1-1/2k) in the classical model. This quantum-classical separation is best possible and resolves a fundamental 19-year old problem. We further obtained an essentially optimal separation of quantum versus classical communication complexity, with bounded error.

 

Broader Impacts

As an integral part of this project, the investigator regularly taught the following undergraduate and graduate courses at UCLA:

  • CS 181 "Formal Languages and Automata," a core undergraduate course on the theory of computation required of all computer science majors at UCLA;
  • CS 281 "Computability and Complexity," a graduate course on computational complexity;
  • CS 289 "Communication Complexity," a graduate introduction to communication complexity theory.  

The student response to these courses has been extraordinary. The investigator consistently receives near-perfect scores for all evaluation criteria. A vast number of students rate the investigator's CS 181 as their favorite class at UCLA, and it has the highest possible rating (5.0 out of 5.0) on UCLA's platform for course reviews, Bruinwalk. Student comments and teaching evaluations reveal a dramatic increase in subject interest: in recent offerings, the subject interest on a 3-point scale was 1.60-1.80 prior to the course versus 2.50+ after.

The investigator has received significant recognition for his teaching at the School and University levels. Over the course of this NSF project, the investigator received the Campus-Wide Distinguished Teaching Award, UCLA's highest teaching honor. Previously, the investigator won the prestigious Northrop-Grumman Excellence in Teaching Award in the School of Engineering at UCLA. As part of this NSF project, the investigator gave three invited lectures entitled "The Art of Great Teaching" in UCLA's School of Engineering, at the personal invitation of UCLA's Associate Dean Richard Wesel.

Outside of his teaching activities, the investigator closely mentors computer science undergraduates interested in pursuing a Ph.D. Many of them are from underrepresented groups. The investigator regularly meets with them to offer career advice, nominates them extensively for fellowships and awards, guides them through the grad school application process, and writes them recommendation letters for admission. In addition to this mentoring, the investigator is the faculty advisor of 30+ undergraduate students and meets with them on a regular basis to guide them in any academic matter and help with their internship and job search.

Over the past years, the investigator has served on approximately 30 Ph.D. and Masters committees at UCLA, in the departments of Computer Science, Mathematics, and Electrical Engineering. This committee service gives the investigator an opportunity to bring his research perspective to other research groups at UCLA and encourage cross-disciplinary thinking.

The investigator is committed to the broadest and most rapid dissemination of his research and teaching materials, making them publicly available on his webpage and preprint websites and giving frequent talks to expert and non-expert audiences.
